Maybe we don’t have to care and privacy becomes the default. I do have a tough time, though, believing companies will be inspired to act without outside pressure.

But if you have ideas, you can always respond to our newsletter with them here: http://tokendaily.co/join-newsletter

1090704787236999168.text: But I do still wonder what it'll take until privacy is naturally prioritized. More FaceTime bugs? More GAFA data breaches (or sales)? I don’t know!

1090704786347851776.text: I'm, of course, not suggesting you physically print out all your data from sites in order to appreciate the gravity of privacy-preservation. That would be environmentally irresponsible.

1090704785429258240.text: Shutting the door is natural because you can physically see it open. Implementing 2FA for the average user isn't natural today - it seems superfluous. Kind of like adding a $20 airline ticket protection when you've never missed a flight in your life.

1090704783546019841.text:
I think about this last quote often because it elegantly articulates what I've always felt on an instinctual, gut-level.

It's easy to be more careless when you don't physically see something happening. It's almost as if it isn't happening at all.pic.twitter.com/n6jbFVc4q0

1090704774607958017.text: “Apps such as Tinder take advantage of a simple emotional phenomenon: we can't feel the data. This is why seeing everything printed strikes you. We are physical creatures. We need materiality."

1090704771730661377.text: One of the best articles I came across that underscored why people are so careless about their digital footprints was by a woman who decided to request all her personal data from Tinder. And she received all 800 *printed* pages.pic.twitter.com/WLVNLhoUW6

1090704764042567680.text:
Where this metaphor falls short, though, is it makes a false equivalency between the physical and the virtual. 

Before joining the cryptocurrency industry, I was in the big data industry. Predictably, privacy is something we spent a lot of time thinking about.

1090704746535514112.text: One of the better responses to the age-old and poorly-thought-through question: "Why should I care about privacy if I have nothing to hide?” is that privacy is the natural state of things and should be the default.
